title: What is a Budgeting?
body: It helps you manage money effectively, reduces financial stress, and increases savings over time. You an achieve goals like traveling, paying off debts, or saving for future needs. Less Stress,  More Savings & Financial Control

title: Setting Financial Goals
body: The 50/30/20 Rule:
Short term (0-1 year): Emergency Fund, Vacation, Goals.
Medium term (1-5 years): Saving for a car, student loans, debts.
Long term (5+ years): Retirement, home ownership, parents retirement.
Specific, Measurable, Achievable, Relevant, Time-bound (SMART) Goals for Financial Success.

title: The 50/30/20 Rule
body: 50% Needs (housing, food, utilities): Essential expenses for basic living.
30% Wants (dining out, hobbies): Non-essential, but enjoyable expenses.
20% Savings (emergency fund, investments): Allocate this portion to savings or debt repayment.
Example Scenario:
Monthly income = $2,000:
20% Savings = $400

title: Tracking and Reviewing Your Budget
body: Daily Log: Apps or journals for daily expenses.
Weekly Review: Check your progress and adjust as needed.
Monthly Adjustments: Tweak the budget based on changes in income or expenses.

title: Tips for Staying on Track
body: Build an Emergency Fund: Aim for 3-6 months of expenses as a safety net.
Automate Savings: Set up automatic transfers to your savings account.
Cut Down on Unnecessary Expenses: Review subscriptions, avoid impulse buys.
Reward Yourself: Celebrate small achievements to stay motivated.

title: Common Budgeting Mistakes
body: Underestimating Expenses: Overestimate to avoid surprise costs.
Ignoring Small Purchases: Small amounts add up over time.
Not Reviewing Regularly: Life changes, and so should your budget.

title: What is a Budget?
back: A budget is a plan for how you will spend and save your money.
It helps you control your spending and reach financial goals.
A good budget tracks both income and expenses.

title: The 50/30/20 Rule

title: Emergency Fund
back: Money set aside for unexpected expenses like medical bills or car repairs.
It helps you avoid debt during emergencies.
Experts recommend saving 3-6 months of living expenses.

title: Fixed vs. Variable Expenses
front: What are Fixed and Variable Expenses?
back: Fixed expenses stay the same each month (e.g., rent, insurance).
Variable expenses change based on usage or need (e.g., groceries, gas).
Knowing the difference helps in creating an accurate budget.

title: Tracking Expenses
back: Tracking helps you see where your money goes.
It helps identify areas where you can cut back.
Use apps or spreadsheets to make tracking easier.

title: Saving for Goals
front: How Do You Save for Financial Goals?
back: Set specific, measurable, and time-bound goals.
Break goals into smaller, manageable steps.
Automate savings to make it consistent.
